# Wall Drug

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[Coordinates](/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system "Geographic coordinate
system"): [43°59′36″N 102°14′30″W﻿ / ﻿43.993231°N 102.241795°W﻿ / 43.993231;
-102.241795](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Wall_Drug&params=43.993231_N_-102.241795_E_)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Wall_Drug_July_2007.jpg/220px-
Wall_Drug_July_2007.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wall_Drug_July_2007.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wall_Drug_July_2007.jpg "Enlarge")

Wall Drug

**Wall Drug Store** , often called simply "Wall Drug," is a [tourist
attraction](/wiki/Tourist_attraction "Tourist attraction") located in the town
of [Wall, South Dakota](/wiki/Wall,_South_Dakota "Wall, South Dakota"). It is
a [shopping mall](/wiki/Shopping_mall "Shopping mall") consisting of a [drug
store](/wiki/Drug_store "Drug store"), [gift shop](/wiki/Gift_shop "Gift
shop"), [restaurants](/wiki/Restaurants "Restaurants") and various other
stores. Unlike a traditional [shopping mall](/wiki/Shopping_mall "Shopping
mall"), all the stores at Wall Drug operate under a single entity instead of
being individually run stores. _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times
"The New York Times")_ has described Wall Drug as "a sprawling tourist
attraction of international renown [that] draws some two million annual
visitors to a remote town."[1]

## Contents

[hide]

  * 1 History
  * 2 Marketing campaign
  * 3 Today
    * 3.1 Media references
  * 4 Gallery
  * 5 See also
  * 6 References
  * 7 External links

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Wall_Drug&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/OldWallDrugs.jpg/220px-
OldWallDrugs.jpg)](/wiki/File:OldWallDrugs.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:OldWallDrugs.jpg "Enlarge")

Wall Drug historic display, including items from Hustead's early practice

The small town drugstore made its first step towards fame when it was
purchased by Ted Hustead in 1931. Hustead was a Nebraska native and pharmacist
who was looking for a small town with a [Catholic
church](/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_the_United_States "Catholic Church in the
United States") in which to establish his business. He bought Wall Drug,
located in a 231-person town in what he referred to as "the middle of
nowhere," and strove to make a living. Business was very slow until his wife,
Dorothy, thought of advertising free ice water to parched travelers heading to
the newly opened [Mount Rushmore](/wiki/Mount_Rushmore "Mount Rushmore")
monument 60 miles (97 km) to the west. From that time on business was brisk.
Wall Drug grew into a [cowboy](/wiki/Cowboy "Cowboy")-themed shopping
mall/[department store](/wiki/Department_store "Department store"). Wall Drug
includes a western art museum, a chapel based on the one found at [New
Melleray Abbey](/wiki/New_Melleray_Abbey "New Melleray Abbey") near [Dubuque,
Iowa](/wiki/Dubuque,_Iowa "Dubuque, Iowa"), and an 80-foot (24 m)
[apatosaurus](/wiki/Apatosaurus "Apatosaurus") (formerly
[brontosaurus](/wiki/Brontosaurus "Brontosaurus")) that can be seen right off
[Interstate 90](/wiki/Interstate_90 "Interstate 90"). It was designed by
[Emmet Sullivan](/wiki/Emmet_Sullivan "Emmet Sullivan") who also created the
dinosaurs at [Dinosaur Park](/wiki/Dinosaur_Park "Dinosaur Park") in [Rapid
City](/wiki/Rapid_City,_South_Dakota "Rapid City, South Dakota") and [Dinosaur
World](/wiki/Dinosaur_World_\(Arkansas\) "Dinosaur World \(Arkansas\)") in
[Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas "Arkansas").

## Marketing
campaign[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Wall_Drug&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Marketing campaign")]

Wall Drug earns much of its fame from its self-promotion.
[Billboards](/wiki/Billboard_\(advertising\) "Billboard \(advertising\)")
advertising the establishment can be seen for hundreds of miles throughout
South Dakota and the neighboring states. In addition, many visitors of Wall
Drug have erected signs throughout the world announcing the miles to Wall Drug
from famous locations. By 1981 Wall Drug was claiming it was giving away
20,000 [cups](/wiki/Cup "Cup") of water per day during the peak tourist
season, lasting from [Memorial Day](/wiki/Memorial_Day "Memorial Day") until
[Labor Day](/wiki/Labor_Day "Labor Day"), and during the hottest days of the
[summer](/wiki/Summer "Summer").

Most of Wall Drug's advertisement billboards can be found on an approximately
650-mile-long (1,050 km) stretch of [Interstate 90](/wiki/Interstate_90
"Interstate 90") from [Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota "Minnesota") to [Billings,
Montana](/wiki/Billings,_Montana "Billings, Montana"). The signs are created
by South Dakota billboard artists, including Dobby Hansen and Barry Knutson of
[Philip](/wiki/Philip,_South_Dakota "Philip, South Dakota") and Mike Kurtz,
KurtzSigns.com [[1]](http://www.KurtzSigns.com) formerly of [Rapid
City](/wiki/Rapid_City,_South_Dakota "Rapid City, South Dakota").[2]

## Today[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Wall_Drug&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Today")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Wall_Drug_Dinosaur.JPG/250px-
Wall_Drug_Dinosaur.JPG)](/wiki/File:Wall_Drug_Dinosaur.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Wall_Drug_Dinosaur.JPG "Enlarge")

The Wall Drug Dinosaur

To date, Wall Drug still offers free ice water, but as they have become more
popular, they have started to offer free [bumper
stickers](/wiki/Bumper_stickers "Bumper stickers") and
[signs](/wiki/Commercial_signage "Commercial signage") to aid in
[promotion](/wiki/Promotion_\(marketing\) "Promotion \(marketing\)"), and
coffee for 5 cents. Some popular free bumper stickers read "Where the heck is
Wall Drug?", "How many miles to Wall Drug?", and "Where in the world is Wall
Drug?".

When the [United States Air Force](/wiki/United_States_Air_Force "United
States Air Force") was still operating [Minuteman
missile](/wiki/LGM-30_Minuteman "LGM-30 Minuteman") silos in the western South
Dakota plains, Wall Drug used to offer free coffee and doughnuts to service
personnel if they stopped in on their way to or from [Ellsworth Air Force
Base](/wiki/Ellsworth_Air_Force_Base "Ellsworth Air Force Base") (50 miles (80
km) west on Interstate 90).

Ted Hustead died in 1999. The following day, South Dakota Governor [Bill
Janklow](/wiki/Bill_Janklow "Bill Janklow") began his annual [State of the
State address](/wiki/State_of_the_State_address "State of the State address")
by commemorating Hustead as "a guy that figured out that free ice water could
turn you into a phenomenal success in the middle of a semi-arid desert way out
in the middle of someplace."[1]

### Media references[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Wall_Drug&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Media references")]

In 1981, Wall Drug was featured in [_Time_ magazine](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\)
"Time \(magazine\)") as one of the largest tourist attractions in the
north.[3] In his 1989 book _[The Lost
Continent](/wiki/The_Lost_Continent:_Travels_in_Small-Town_America "The Lost
Continent: Travels in Small-Town America")_ , [Bill Bryson](/wiki/Bill_Bryson
"Bill Bryson") wrote, "It's an awful place, one of the world's worst [tourist
traps](/wiki/Tourist_trap "Tourist trap"), but I loved it and I won't have a
word said against it."[4] The history of Wall Drug was told in a two-episode
story arc of the podcast _[The Radio Adventures of Dr.
Floyd](/wiki/The_Radio_Adventures_of_Dr._Floyd "The Radio Adventures of Dr.
Floyd")_. In 2016 "Z Nation" featured wall Drug in season 3, episode 8.
